prop.head.headtext: Thorburn, Law of Confidential Business Information

head.headtext: The Quality of Confidence—Intentional public disclosure

para.paratext: Where there is public disclosure by the “owner” or person in rightful possession of information, e.g., to obtain a patent or to promote a product, the courts will find that the information in issue can no longer be considered confidential.[1] For example, where the relevant information is published in a company's annual reports or voluntarily filed with and accessible through governmental authorities, it will generally lose confidential status. However, with respect to the protections available for information filed with the government, see section 8:5.

The claim for a breach of confidence in Boaden Catering Ltd. v. Real Food for Real Kids Inc.[2] could not succeed based upon the first two elements, a) that the information conveyed was confidential; and b) that it was communicated in confidence. Boaden and RFRK were competitors. RFRK specialized in providing catering services geared to young people such as children attending day care or before and after school programs. Boaden had a broader based catering business which had a division called Organic Kids Catering. RFRK retained Terry, a private investigator, and she met with Tassone posing as a prospective customer. The information conveyed was not confidential. It was information that Tassone was prepared to share with any prospective customer. Further, Tassone agreed that it was not communicated in confidence. He did not require any confidentiality agreement or even suggest to Terry that the information was confidential. The claim for breach of confidence related to alleged theft of trade secrets and corporate espionage was, therefore, dismissed.[3]

In Cana International Distributing Inc. v. Standard Innovation Corp.,[4] Cana's action against Standard Innovation for breach of contract alleging that Cana had exclusive distribution agreements with Standard Innovation with respect to the distribution of an adult sex toy was dismissed.[5]

Standard Innovation counterclaimed against Cana and its principal, Ciolli. In an email to Health Canada, Ciolli requested an official inquiry into the safety and compliance of all We-Vibe products. Ciolli's statement set out the alleged safety concerns and stated that she was in receipt of approximately 100-150 letters from Canadian retailers and end consumers with proof of purchase reporting defects with We-Vibe products. Additionally, her e-mail stated that she was in possession of a significant quantity of defective products including a return from a consumer reporting that her product emitted smoke and evidence of melting. The e-mail stated that she was prepared to provide, if requested by Health Canada, a copy of these letters as well as defective product returns for review and product safety testing purposes. The e-mail also stated that that one or more of the claims being made on the product packaging were not truthful. In particular, the claims that ‘The Products’ are Phthalate Free, Lead Free, CE Compliant & Carbon Neutral. She stated that she was in possession of correspondence from the manufacturer's representative stating that these specific claims on the packaging may not be truthful.[6]

At trial, Ciolli admitted that she had no evidence of any safety or compliance issues with the Tango, Touch, and Salsa despite mentioning these products in her statement. Cana had never distributed these products or the We-Vibe III. Following the delivery of Ciolli's statement of complaint, Health Canada commenced an investigation and contacted Standard Innovation for a response. Prior to being contacted by Health Canada, Standard Innovation had no knowledge that Ciolli had any safety concerns about any of its products. Immediately after receiving a copy of the statement from Health Canada, Standard Innovation wrote to Ciolli requesting all evidence of defects leading to the injury of customers and all information about the consumer reporting that her product emitted smoke and evidence of melting. Standard Innovation never received a response to this request. Shortly after receiving Standard Innovation's response, Health Canada discontinued its investigation. In addition to writing to Health Canada, Ciolli wrote to the Competition Bureau of Canada making similar allegations. The Bureau declined to undertake an investigation.[7]

The trial judge observed that the statements made by Ciolli were serious and suggested that the We-Vibe II posed a danger to users and could possibly explode and catch on fire. There was no evidence that suggested that the device caught fire or that it presented a risk of explosion.[8]

Standard Innovation submitted that, as the distributor for Standard Innovation, the defendants were privy to Standard Innovation's proprietary and confidential information about Standard Innovation's products, company, and customer correspondence, and had a duty to keep this information confidential. The defendants responded by arguing that the information communicated to Health Canada concerned consumer complaints about the We-Vibe that potentially caused a health risk, along with issues related to packaging information. None of this information was supplied by Standard Innovation to Cana in confidence. The trial judge agreed with the position of the defendants and found that the information communicated to Health Canada and the Competition Bureau was not provided in circumstances of confidence. Accordingly, this claim was dismissed.[9]

In Mobil Oil Canada, Ltd. v. Canadian Superior Oil Ltd.,[10] the Alberta Supreme Court reviewed a situation where the plaintiff's former president and general manager, the defendant Nielson, terminated his employment in order to join the corporate defendant, Canadian Superior Oil Ltd., as a director and executive vice-president. Mobil Oil alleged that Nielsen had been privy, during the course of his former employment, to trade secrets and confidential information that would be of benefit to Canadian Superior. The court found that, on the evidence, Nielsen did not have direct personal knowledge of the various subject-matters in dispute. Further, with respect to Nielsen's alleged knowledge of the plaintiff's “reserve estimates”, the court held that:
… the information [was] not confidential, being regularly published [in] annual reports and filed with the Oil and Gas Conservation Board in Alberta and with similar authorities in other Provinces.

In view of the publication of revenue estimates in a producing field, the short duration of a reserve estimate for an individual property in which a company proposes to drill a wildcat well, the variability of reserve estimates for large areas and their being publicized, this information cannot be regarded as confidential and proprietary …[11]

Franchi, [1967] R.P.C. 149 (Ch.); Fraser v. Thames Television Ltd., [1983] 2 All E.R. 101 (Q.B.). See also Kewanee Oil Co. v. Bicron Corp., 416 U.S. 470 (1974); Underwater Storage, Inc. v. United States Rubber Co., 125 U.S. App. D.C. 297, 371 F.2d 950 (1966), cert. denied 386 U.S. 911 (1967); and Justice Brandeis, dissenting, in International News Service v. Associated Press, 248 U.S. 215, 250 (1918): “The general rule of law is, that the noblest of human productions—knowledge, truths ascertained, conceptions, and ideas—become, after voluntary communication to others, free as the air to common use.” The mere application for a patent may not be a disclosure to the public: Scharmer v. Carrollton Mfg. Co., 525 F.2d 95, 187 U.S.P.Q. 736 (1975). In addition, limited publication for a restricted purpose may not destroy confidentiality: Space Aero Products Co. v. R.E. Darling Co., 238 Md. 93, 208 A.2d 74 (1965).
